Orgnztion: Southern California Coastal Water Research Project

Notes: We hope to continue the Bight Acidification sampling into the future as funding allows; http://ftp.sccwrp.org/pub/download/DOCUMENTS/BightPlanningDocuments/Bight13/Bight13_Nutrients_Workplan.pdf

URL: Now: available upon request; future: Bight database
Notes: We hope to continue the Bight Acidification sampling into the future as funding allows; http://ftp.sccwrp.org/pub/download/DOCUMENTS/BightPlanningDocuments/Bight13/Bight13_Nutrients_Workplan.pdf
Methods: pH: m-cresol purple spectrophotometric technique (Carter et al. 2013); TA: open-cell potentiometric titration (Dickson et al. 2003)
Instrument: CTD vertical profiles will be conducted using SeaBird CTDs equipped with auxiliary sensors to measure dissolved oxygen, pH, beam transmission (turbidity), chlorophyll fluorescence, and CDOM fluorescence

Instrument: Seabird 24-position carousel s/n 471; 9plus CTD s/n 315;primary 3plus temperature sensor s/n 03P-4569 (stations 1-34) and 03P-4335 (stations 35-111);primary 4C conductivity sensor s/n 04-3157 (stations 1-34) and 04-2887 (stations 35-111);secondary 3plus temperature sensor s/n 03P-4341 and secondary 4C conductivity sensor s/n 04-3068; and oxygen s/n 43-0313 (stations 1-34) and 43-0315 (stations 35-111)
OtherPhys: Total Carbon; Ar and O2 isotopes

ProjectID: Southern California Bight Regional Monitoring Program 2013: Synoptic Survey of Acidification in the Bight
Orgnztion: Southern California Coastal Water Research Project
URL: Now: available upon request; future: Bight database
Notes: We hope to continue the Bight Acidification sampling into the future as funding allows; http://ftp.sccwrp.org/pub/download/DOCUMENTS/BightPlanningDocuments/Bight13/Bight13_Nutrients_Workplan.pdf
Methods: pH: m-cresol purple spectrophotometric technique (Carter et al. 2013); TA: open-cell potentiometric titration (Dickson et al. 2003)
Instrument: bottle samples at 2 depths for pH and TA; CTD vertical profiles will be conducted using SeaBird CTDs equipped with auxiliary sensors to measure dissolved oxygen, pH, beam transmission (turbidity), chlorophyll fluorescence, and CDOM fluorescence

OtherPhys: Total Carbon; Ar and O2 isotopes

Orgnztion: University of California Santa Cruz
FunderName: The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, and many other sources
FundSec: Continued funding is likely from the same source
MeasPeriod: spring & fall (south of SF); summer (north of SF)
Methods: Temperature loggers are launched in the lab and then deployed in the field. In general, loggers are set to record temperatures every 15 minutes; however, depending on the memory available in the logger and the intended length of deployment, sometimes loggers are set to record temperatures every 30 minutes. The loggers are launched using a delayed start to ensure the temperatures are recorded starting on the hour. In the field, temperature loggers are attached to the inside of a small metal cage using cable ties. These cages are secured to the rock below the lower edge of the mussel zone using lag screws and wall anchors. One logger is deployed per site.
Instrument: TidBits and HOBOs from Onset Computer Corporation
BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae

FunderName: The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, and many other sources
FundSec: Continued funding is likely from the same source
MeasPeriod: spring & fall (south of SF); summer (north of SF)
Methods: Temperature loggers are launched in the lab and then deployed in the field. In general, loggers are set to record temperatures every 15 minutes; however, depending on the memory available in the logger and the intended length of deployment, sometimes loggers are set to record temperatures every 30 minutes. The loggers are launched using a delayed start to ensure the temperatures are recorded starting on the hour. In the field, temperature loggers are attached to the inside of a small metal cage using cable ties. These cages are secured to the rock below the lower edge of the mussel zone using lag screws and wall anchors. One logger is deployed per site.
Instrument: TidBits and HOBOs from Onset Computer Corporation
BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae

Orgnztion: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration - Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory
FundSec: Not pursuing continued funding
Methods: Deep cast rosette; underway optical sensors
Instrument: Seabird 24-position carousel s/n 471; 9plus CTD s/n 315;primary 3plus temperature sensor s/n 03P-4569 (stations 1-34) and 03P-4335 (stations 35-111);primary 4C conductivity sensor s/n 04-3157 (stations 1-34) and 04-2887 (stations 35-111);secondary 3plus temperature sensor s/n 03P-4341 and secondary 4C conductivity sensor s/n 04-3068; and oxygen s/n 43-0313 (stations 1-34) and 43-0315 (stations 35-111)
OtherPhys: Total Carbon; Ar and O2 isotopes

Orgnztion: University of California Santa Cruz
FunderName: The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, and many other sources
FundSec: Continued funding is likely from the same source
MeasPeriod: spring & fall (south of SF); summer (north of SF)
Methods: Temperature loggers are launched in the lab and then deployed in the field. In general, loggers are set to record temperatures every 15 minutes; however, depending on the memory available in the logger and the intended length of deployment, sometimes loggers are set to record temperatures every 30 minutes. The loggers are launched using a delayed start to ensure the temperatures are recorded starting on the hour. In the field, temperature loggers are attached to the inside of a small metal cage using cable ties. These cages are secured to the rock below the lower edge of the mussel zone using lag screws and wall anchors. One logger is deployed per site.
Instrument: TidBits and HOBOs from Onset Computer Corporation
BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae

DataFreq: Data uploaded to ERDDAP once a year

Instrument: CTD, SBE 19+, Thermosalinometer, SBE 21 and 101

The loggers are launched using a delayed start to ensure the temperatures are recorded starting on the hour. In the field, temperature loggers are attached to the inside of a small metal cage using cable ties. These cages are secured to the rock below the lower edge of the mussel zone using lag screws and wall anchors. One logger is deployed per site.
Instrument: TidBits and HOBOs from Onset Computer Corporation
BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae

FunderName: The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, and many other sources
FundSec: Continued funding is likely from the same source
MeasPeriod: spring & fall (south of SF); summer (north of SF)
Methods: Temperature loggers are launched in the lab and then deployed in the field. In general, loggers are set to record temperatures every 15 minutes; however, depending on the memory available in the logger and the intended length of deployment, sometimes loggers are set to record temperatures every 30 minutes. The loggers are launched using a delayed start to ensure the temperatures are recorded starting on the hour. In the field, temperature loggers are attached to the inside of a small metal cage using cable ties. These cages are secured to the rock below the lower edge of the mussel zone using lag screws and wall anchors. One logger is deployed per site.
Instrument: TidBits and HOBOs from Onset Computer Corporation
BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae

Orgnztion: University of California Santa Cruz
FunderName: The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, and many other sources
FundSec: Continued funding is likely from the same source
MeasPeriod: spring & fall (south of SF); summer (north of SF)
Methods: Temperature loggers are launched in the lab and then deployed in the field. In general, loggers are set to record temperatures every 15 minutes; however, depending on the memory available in the logger and the intended length of deployment, sometimes loggers are set to record temperatures every 30 minutes. The loggers are launched using a delayed start to ensure the temperatures are recorded starting on the hour. In the field, temperature loggers are attached to the inside of a small metal cage using cable ties. These cages are secured to the rock below the lower edge of the mussel zone using lag screws and wall anchors. One logger is deployed per site.
Instrument: TidBits and HOBOs from Onset Computer Corporation
BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae

Orgnztion: University of California Santa Cruz
FunderName: The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, and many other sources
FundSec: Continued funding is likely from the same source
MeasPeriod: spring & fall (south of SF); summer (north of SF)
Methods: Temperature loggers are launched in the lab and then deployed in the field. In general, loggers are set to record temperatures every 15 minutes; however, depending on the memory available in the logger and the intended length of deployment, sometimes loggers are set to record temperatures every 30 minutes. The loggers are launched using a delayed start to ensure the temperatures are recorded starting on the hour. In the field, temperature loggers are attached to the inside of a small metal cage using cable ties. These cages are secured to the rock below the lower edge of the mussel zone using lag screws and wall anchors. One logger is deployed per site.
Instrument: TidBits and HOBOs from Onset Computer Corporation
BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae

Orgnztion: University of Washington; National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration

Orgnztion: University of California Santa Cruz
FunderName: The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, and many other sources
FundSec: Continued funding is likely from the same source
MeasPeriod: spring & fall (south of SF); summer (north of SF)
Methods: Temperature loggers are launched in the lab and then deployed in the field. In general, loggers are set to record temperatures every 15 minutes; however, depending on the memory available in the logger and the intended length of deployment, sometimes loggers are set to record temperatures every 30 minutes. The loggers are launched using a delayed start to ensure the temperatures are recorded starting on the hour. In the field, temperature loggers are attached to the inside of a small metal cage using cable ties. These cages are secured to the rock below the lower edge of the mussel zone using lag screws and wall anchors. One logger is deployed per site.
Instrument: TidBits and HOBOs from Onset Computer Corporation
BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae

Orgnztion: University of California Santa Cruz
FunderName: The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, and many other sources
FundSec: Continued funding is likely from the same source
MeasPeriod: spring & fall (south of SF); summer (north of SF)
Methods: Temperature loggers are launched in the lab and then deployed in the field. In general, loggers are set to record temperatures every 15 minutes; however, depending on the memory available in the logger and the intended length of deployment, sometimes loggers are set to record temperatures every 30 minutes. The loggers are launched using a delayed start to ensure the temperatures are recorded starting on the hour. In the field, temperature loggers are attached to the inside of a small metal cage using cable ties. These cages are secured to the rock below the lower edge of the mussel zone using lag screws and wall anchors. One logger is deployed per site.
Instrument: TidBits and HOBOs from Onset Computer Corporation
BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae

Orgnztion: University of California Santa Cruz
FunderName: The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, and many other sources
FundSec: Continued funding is likely from the same source
MeasPeriod: spring & fall (south of SF); summer (north of SF)
Methods: Temperature loggers are launched in the lab and then deployed in the field. In general, loggers are set to record temperatures every 15 minutes; however, depending on the memory available in the logger and the intended length of deployment, sometimes loggers are set to record temperatures every 30 minutes. The loggers are launched using a delayed start to ensure the temperatures are recorded starting on the hour. In the field, temperature loggers are attached to the inside of a small metal cage using cable ties. These cages are secured to the rock below the lower edge of the mussel zone using lag screws and wall anchors. One logger is deployed per site.
Instrument: TidBits and HOBOs from Onset Computer Corporation
BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae

Orgnztion: Oregon State University
Instrument: MBARI (G. Friederich)-designed Durafet-based pH sensor

Orgnztion: United States Department of Agriculture - Agriculture Research Service
FundSec: Continued funding is likely from the same source
BioFocus: Shellfish Population Assessment; Shellfish Abundance and Distribution
Methods: Adult shrimp are extracted out of a stainless steel tube,  sorted through a 3mm sieve and measured for size, sex, parasite presence. Survey was intially a hap hazard design that has transitioned to a stratified random sampling method where 10 random cores are taken within a 1 roughly hectare grid. The relative density of shrimp and other organisms is assesed by counting burrows, habitat type is also assesed across a 25m uniform grid. Recruits are extracted using a clam gun and sorted out through a 1.0 mm sieve.

Orgnztion: United States Department of Agriculture - Agriculture Research Service
BioFocus: Shellfish Population Assessment; Shellfish Abundance and Distribution
Methods: Adult shrimp are extracted out of a stainless steel tube,  sorted through a 3mm sieve and measured for size, sex, parasite presence. Survey was intially a hap hazard design that has transitioned to a stratified random sampling method where 10 random cores are taken within a 1 roughly hectare grid. The relative density of shrimp and other organisms is assesed by counting burrows, habitat type is also assesed across a 25m uniform grid. Recruits are extracted using a clam gun and sorted out through a 1.0 mm sieve.

Notes: Nutrients only measured to 3 m depth. DO sensor was added in September 2006. Surveys have run annualy in June since 1998 until present. Surveys have also ran annually in May from 1999 through 2012. Sampling in May begain in 2015 but not at transects or stations and only around Willapa Bay to the Columbia River. Surveys also ran annualy in September from 1999 through 2012. Not all transects were sampled during any month. In may generally;3 to 8 transects were sampled;in June 5 - 9 transects were sampled;and in September 3 - 8 transects were sampled. Juvenile salmon and associated enkton are colleted using a nordic rope trawl in the upper water column (around 18 m).
FundSec: Current funding has option for renewal
DataFreq: Data uploaded to NOAA server after each survey

Orgnztion: University of California Santa Cruz
FunderName: The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, and many other sources
FundSec: Continued funding is likely from the same source
MeasPeriod: spring & fall (south of SF); summer (north of SF)
Methods: Temperature loggers are launched in the lab and then deployed in the field. In general, loggers are set to record temperatures every 15 minutes; however, depending on the memory available in the logger and the intended length of deployment, sometimes loggers are set to record temperatures every 30 minutes. The loggers are launched using a delayed start to ensure the temperatures are recorded starting on the hour. In the field, temperature loggers are attached to the inside of a small metal cage using cable ties. These cages are secured to the rock below the lower edge of the mussel zone using lag screws and wall anchors. One logger is deployed per site.
Instrument: TidBits and HOBOs from Onset Computer Corporation
BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae

Orgnztion: National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration - Northwest Fisheries Science Center, Oregon State University, Oregon Health & Science University
Notes: Nutrients only measured to 3 m depth. DO sensor was added in September 2006. Surveys have run annualy in June since 1998 until present. Surveys have also ran annually in May from 1999 through 2012. Sampling in May begain in 2015 but not at transects or stations and only around Willapa Bay to the Columbia River. Surveys also ran annualy in September from 1999 through 2012. Not all transects were sampled during any month. In may generally;3 to 8 transects were sampled;in June 5 - 9 transects were sampled;and in September 3 - 8 transects were sampled. Juvenile salmon and associated enkton are colleted using a nordic rope trawl in the upper water column (around 18 m).
FundSec: Current funding has option for renewal
DataFreq: Data uploaded to NOAA server after each survey

Orgnztion: United States Department of Agriculture - Agriculture Research Service
BioFocus: Shellfish Population Assessment; Shellfish Abundance and Distribution
Methods: Adult shrimp are extracted out of a stainless steel tube,  sorted through a 3mm sieve and measured for size, sex, parasite presence. Survey was intially a hap hazard design that has transitioned to a stratified random sampling method where 10 random cores are taken within a 1 roughly hectare grid. The relative density of shrimp and other organisms is assesed by counting burrows, habitat type is also assesed across a 25m uniform grid. Recruits are extracted using a clam gun and sorted out through a 1.0 mm sieve.

FunderName: The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, and many other sources
FundSec: Continued funding is likely from the same source
MeasPeriod: spring & fall (south of SF); summer (north of SF)
Methods: Temperature loggers are launched in the lab and then deployed in the field. In general, loggers are set to record temperatures every 15 minutes; however, depending on the memory available in the logger and the intended length of deployment, sometimes loggers are set to record temperatures every 30 minutes. The loggers are launched using a delayed start to ensure the temperatures are recorded starting on the hour. In the field, temperature loggers are attached to the inside of a small metal cage using cable ties. These cages are secured to the rock below the lower edge of the mussel zone using lag screws and wall anchors. One logger is deployed per site.
Instrument: TidBits and HOBOs from Onset Computer Corporation
BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae

Orgnztion: National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration - Northwest Fisheries Science Center, Oregon State University, Oregon Health & Science University
Notes: Nutrients only measured to 3 m depth. DO sensor was added in September 2006. Surveys have run annualy in June since 1998 until present. Surveys have also ran annually in May from 1999 through 2012. Sampling in May begain in 2015 but not at transects or stations and only around Willapa Bay to the Columbia River. Surveys also ran annualy in September from 1999 through 2012. Not all transects were sampled during any month. In may generally;3 to 8 transects were sampled;in June 5 - 9 transects were sampled;and in September 3 - 8 transects were sampled. Juvenile salmon and associated enkton are colleted using a nordic rope trawl in the upper water column (around 18 m).
FundSec: Current funding has option for renewal
DataFreq: Data uploaded to NOAA server after each survey

Orgnztion: University of California Santa Cruz
FunderName: The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, and many other sources
FundSec: Continued funding is likely from the same source
MeasPeriod: spring & fall (south of SF); summer (north of SF)
Methods: Temperature loggers are launched in the lab and then deployed in the field. In general, loggers are set to record temperatures every 15 minutes; however, depending on the memory available in the logger and the intended length of deployment, sometimes loggers are set to record temperatures every 30 minutes. The loggers are launched using a delayed start to ensure the temperatures are recorded starting on the hour. In the field, temperature loggers are attached to the inside of a small metal cage using cable ties. These cages are secured to the rock below the lower edge of the mussel zone using lag screws and wall anchors. One logger is deployed per site.
Instrument: TidBits and HOBOs from Onset Computer Corporation
BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae

Orgnztion: United States Department of Agriculture - Agriculture Research Service
BioFocus: Shellfish Population Assessment; Shellfish Abundance and Distribution
Methods: Adult shrimp are extracted out of a stainless steel tube,  sorted through a 3mm sieve and measured for size, sex, parasite presence. Survey was intially a hap hazard design that has transitioned to a stratified random sampling method where 10 random cores are taken within a 1 roughly hectare grid. The relative density of shrimp and other organisms is assesed by counting burrows, habitat type is also assesed across a 25m uniform grid. Recruits are extracted using a clam gun and sorted out through a 1.0 mm sieve.

Orgnztion: University of California Santa Cruz
FunderName: The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, and many other sources
FundSec: Continued funding is likely from the same source
MeasPeriod: spring & fall (south of SF); summer (north of SF)
Methods: Temperature loggers are launched in the lab and then deployed in the field. In general, loggers are set to record temperatures every 15 minutes; however, depending on the memory available in the logger and the intended length of deployment, sometimes loggers are set to record temperatures every 30 minutes. The loggers are launched using a delayed start to ensure the temperatures are recorded starting on the hour. In the field, temperature loggers are attached to the inside of a small metal cage using cable ties. These cages are secured to the rock below the lower edge of the mussel zone using lag screws and wall anchors. One logger is deployed per site.
Instrument: TidBits and HOBOs from Onset Computer Corporation
BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae

Surveys also ran annualy in September from 1999 through 2012. Not all transects were sampled during any month. In may generally;3 to 8 transects were sampled;in June 5 - 9 transects were sampled;and in September 3 - 8 transects were sampled. Juvenile salmon and associated enkton are colleted using a nordic rope trawl in the upper water column (around 18 m).
FundSec: Current funding has option for renewal
DataFreq: Data uploaded to NOAA server after each survey

Orgnztion: University of California Santa Cruz
FunderName: The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, and many other sources
FundSec: Continued funding is likely from the same source
MeasPeriod: spring & fall (south of SF); summer (north of SF)
Methods: Temperature loggers are launched in the lab and then deployed in the field. In general, loggers are set to record temperatures every 15 minutes; however, depending on the memory available in the logger and the intended length of deployment, sometimes loggers are set to record temperatures every 30 minutes. The loggers are launched using a delayed start to ensure the temperatures are recorded starting on the hour. In the field, temperature loggers are attached to the inside of a small metal cage using cable ties. These cages are secured to the rock below the lower edge of the mussel zone using lag screws and wall anchors. One logger is deployed per site.
Instrument: TidBits and HOBOs from Onset Computer Corporation
BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae

Orgnztion: National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration - Northwest Fisheries Science Center, Oregon State University, Oregon Health & Science University
Notes: Nutrients only measured to 3 m depth. DO sensor was added in September 2006. Surveys have run annualy in June since 1998 until present. Surveys have also ran annually in May from 1999 through 2012. Sampling in May begain in 2015 but not at transects or stations and only around Willapa Bay to the Columbia River. Surveys also ran annualy in September from 1999 through 2012. Not all transects were sampled during any month. In may generally;3 to 8 transects were sampled;in June 5 - 9 transects were sampled;and in September 3 - 8 transects were sampled. Juvenile salmon and associated enkton are colleted using a nordic rope trawl in the upper water column (around 18 m).
FundSec: Current funding has option for renewal
DataFreq: Data uploaded to NOAA server after each survey

Orgnztion: University of California Santa Cruz
FunderName: The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, and many other sources
FundSec: Continued funding is likely from the same source
MeasPeriod: spring & fall (south of SF); summer (north of SF)
Methods: Temperature loggers are launched in the lab and then deployed in the field. In general, loggers are set to record temperatures every 15 minutes; however, depending on the memory available in the logger and the intended length of deployment, sometimes loggers are set to record temperatures every 30 minutes. The loggers are launched using a delayed start to ensure the temperatures are recorded starting on the hour. In the field, temperature loggers are attached to the inside of a small metal cage using cable ties. These cages are secured to the rock below the lower edge of the mussel zone using lag screws and wall anchors. One logger is deployed per site.
Instrument: TidBits and HOBOs from Onset Computer Corporation
BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae

Orgnztion: National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration - Northwest Fisheries Science Center, Oregon State University, Oregon Health & Science University
Notes: Nutrients only measured to 3 m depth. DO sensor was added in September 2006. Surveys have run annualy in June since 1998 until present. Surveys have also ran annually in May from 1999 through 2012. Sampling in May begain in 2015 but not at transects or stations and only around Willapa Bay to the Columbia River. Surveys also ran annualy in September from 1999 through 2012. Not all transects were sampled during any month. In may generally;3 to 8 transects were sampled;in June 5 - 9 transects were sampled;and in September 3 - 8 transects were sampled. Juvenile salmon and associated enkton are colleted using a nordic rope trawl in the upper water column (around 18 m).
FundSec: Current funding has option for renewal
DataFreq: Data uploaded to NOAA server after each survey

Notes: Survey is primarily an index survey of locations where urchins are know to occur and checked as a reference of relative abundance. Non-random survey. Orgnztion: University of California Santa Cruz
FunderName: The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, and many other sources
FundSec: Continued funding is likely from the same source
MeasPeriod: spring & fall (south of SF); summer (north of SF)
Methods: Temperature loggers are launched in the lab and then deployed in the field. In general, loggers are set to record temperatures every 15 minutes; however, depending on the memory available in the logger and the intended length of deployment, sometimes loggers are set to record temperatures every 30 minutes. The loggers are launched using a delayed start to ensure the temperatures are recorded starting on the hour. In the field, temperature loggers are attached to the inside of a small metal cage using cable ties. These cages are secured to the rock below the lower edge of the mussel zone using lag screws and wall anchors. One logger is deployed per site.
Instrument: TidBits and HOBOs from Onset Computer Corporation
BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae

Orgnztion: University of Chicago
Notes: To understand how ocean conditions influence population and ecological community dynamics of rocky shore habitats we initiated measurements of key physical/chemical parameters at Tatoosh Island Washington in June 2000 including water temperature dissolved oxygen pH and salinity/conductivity. Measures were made with a Hydrolab DS4a/DS5x logging probe at half hour intervals during spring-late summer in each year. Submitted data were collected through August 2010. The probe was deployed at biweekly-monthly intervals with cleaning and calibration done in a 12-24 hr period before probe redeployment. The probe was secured to the shoreline of Tatoosh Island and was housed in a 5000 l tidepool separated from the ocean by a 1 wide lip at a tide height of 80 cm to assure that probe performance was not compromised by desiccation at low tide. These data form the core of analyses in Pfister et al. (L&O 2007) Wootton et al. (PNAS 2008) and Wootton and Pfister (PLoS ONE In Press 2012).
FundSec: Not pursuing continued funding
Instrument: Hydrolab DS4a/DS5x logging probe

FunderName: The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, and many other sources

BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae

Orgnztion: National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration - Northwest Fisheries Science Center, Oregon State University, Oregon Health & Science University
Notes: Nutrients only measured to 3 m depth. DO sensor was added in September 2006. Surveys have run annualy in June since 1998 until present. Surveys have also ran annually in May from 1999 through 2012. Sampling in May begain in 2015 but not at transects or stations and only around Willapa Bay to the Columbia River. Surveys also ran annualy in September from 1999 through 2012. Not all transects were sampled during any month. In may generally;3 to 8 transects were sampled;in June 5 - 9 transects were sampled;and in September 3 - 8 transects were sampled. Juvenile salmon and associated enkton are colleted using a nordic rope trawl in the upper water column (around 18 m).
FundSec: Current funding has option for renewal
DataFreq: Data uploaded to NOAA server after each survey

Orgnztion: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration - Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory
FundSec: Not pursuing continued funding
Methods: Deep cast rosette; underway optical sensors
Instrument: Seabird 24-position carousel s/n 471; 9plus CTD s/n 315;primary 3plus temperature sensor s/n 03P-4569 (stations 1-34) and 03P-4335 (stations 35-111);primary 4C conductivity sensor s/n 04-3157 (stations 1-34) and 04-2887 (stations 35-111);secondary 3plus temperature sensor s/n 03P-4341 and secondary 4C conductivity sensor s/n 04-3068; and oxygen s/n 43-0313 (stations 1-34) and 43-0315 (stations 35-111)
OtherPhys: Total Carbon; Ar and O2 isotopes

Orgnztion: National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration - Northwest Fisheries Science Center, Oregon State University, Oregon Health & Science University
Notes: Nutrients only measured to 3 m depth. DO sensor was added in September 2006. Surveys have run annualy in June since 1998 until present. Surveys have also ran annually in May from 1999 through 2012. Sampling in May begain in 2015 but not at transects or stations and only around Willapa Bay to the Columbia River. Surveys also ran annualy in September from 1999 through 2012. Not all transects were sampled during any month. In may generally;3 to 8 transects were sampled;in June 5 - 9 transects were sampled;and in September 3 - 8 transects were sampled. Juvenile salmon and associated enkton are colleted using a nordic rope trawl in the upper water column (around 18 m).
FundSec: Current funding has option for renewal
DataFreq: Data uploaded to NOAA server after each survey

Orgnztion: University of Washington;  National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration - Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory
Notes: pCO2 data real-time but other sensors not providing data as of Jan-Feb 2014. "Main telemetry stopped as of 10/22/13 but data loggers continuing to transmit normally".
Email: newton@apl.washington.edu; adrienne.sutton@noaa.gov for CO2/OA mooring time series
FundSec: Current funding has option for renewal
Methods: http://wavechasers.apl.washington.edu/projects/active-projects/nemo
Instrument: pCO2 sensor WQM SAMI pH SeaFET SBE39 temp SBE37 ODO

Orgnztion: National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration - Northwest Fisheries Science Center, Oregon State University, Oregon Health & Science University
Notes: Nutrients only measured to 3 m depth. DO sensor was added in September 2006. Surveys have run annualy in June since 1998 until present. Surveys have also ran annually in May from 1999 through 2012. Sampling in May begain in 2015 but not at transects or stations and only around Willapa Bay to the Columbia River. Surveys also ran annualy in September from 1999 through 2012. Not all transects were sampled during any month. In may generally;3 to 8 transects were sampled;in June 5 - 9 transects were sampled;and in September 3 - 8 transects were sampled. Juvenile salmon and associated enkton are colleted using a nordic rope trawl in the upper water column (around 18 m).
FundSec: Current funding has option for renewal
DataFreq: Data uploaded to NOAA server after each survey

Instrument: Seabird 24-position carousel s/n 471; 9plus CTD s/n 315;primary 3plus temperature sensor s/n 03P-4569 (stations 1-34) and 03P-4335 (stations 35-111);primary 4C conductivity sensor s/n 04-3157 (stations 1-34) and 04-2887 (stations 35-111);secondary 3plus temperature sensor s/n 03P-4341 and secondary 4C conductivity sensor s/n 04-3068; and oxygen s/n 43-0313 (stations 1-34) and 43-0315 (stations 35-111)
OtherPhys: Total Carbon; Ar and O2 isotopes

Orgnztion: University of California Santa Cruz
FunderName: The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, and many other sources
FundSec: Continued funding is likely from the same source
MeasPeriod: spring & fall (south of SF); summer (north of SF)
Methods: Temperature loggers are launched in the lab and then deployed in the field. In general, loggers are set to record temperatures every 15 minutes; however, depending on the memory available in the logger and the intended length of deployment, sometimes loggers are set to record temperatures every 30 minutes. The loggers are launched using a delayed start to ensure the temperatures are recorded starting on the hour. In the field, temperature loggers are attached to the inside of a small metal cage using cable ties. These cages are secured to the rock below the lower edge of the mussel zone using lag screws and wall anchors. One logger is deployed per site.
Instrument: TidBits and HOBOs from Onset Computer Corporation
BioSamples: Shellfish; Seagrass; Kelp; Intertidal Invertebrates; Algae
